comments:
This class combines theory with practice, as students will learn about the contemporary mural movement and then design and paint a large outdoor mural in West Philadelphia in collaboration with Philadelphia high school students.
 Students “learned a lot” in this “unique” course, described by many as the best class they’ve taken at Penn. Students not only learn about the public arts process, but also take full part in it, learning “actual life skills such as community grass-roots organizing, event planning, etc.” Assigned reading materials were “interesting” and prepared students for issues that would come up in the implementation of their project. Written assignments “helped us understand” the complexities of public art. Design projects were “fun” and “helpful,” especially for those who had little exposure to design. Students enjoyed taking full ownership of the “preparation and execution” of their community project, describing it as a “fantastic experience.” 
Instructor Jane Golden is the founder and Director of the Philadelphia Mural Arts Program, and thus unmatched in relevant knowledge and experience. Students described the instructor team as “extraordinarily knowledgeable and helpful,” and as being “fantastic at what they do.”
The interesting topics, fun activities, and comfortable class atmosphere contributed to student’s satisfaction with this course. Despite its niche in the Fine Arts Department, students unanimously “recommend it to any student at Penn.” One student summed up the course as “AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME,” and others praised it as the “highlight of my undergraduate career.”

This class combines theory with practice, as students will learn about the contemporary mural movement and then design and paint a large outdoor mural in West Philadelphia in collaboration with Philadelphia high school students.
 Students “learned a lot” in this “unique” course, described by many as the best class they’ve taken at Penn. Students not only learn about the public arts process, but also take full part in it, learning “actual life skills such as community grass-roots organizing, event planning, etc.” Assigned reading materials were “interesting” and prepared students for issues that would come up in the implementation of their project. Written assignments “helped us understand” the complexities of public art. Design projects were “fun” and “helpful,” especially for those who had little exposure to design. Students enjoyed taking full ownership of the “preparation and execution” of their community project, describing it as a “fantastic experience.” 
Both instructors are unmatched in experience and relevant knowledge. Donald Gensler has completed over 35 public arts projects nationally, and Jane Golden is the founder and Director of the Philadelphia Mural Arts Program. Students described the instructor team as “extraordinarily knowledgeable and helpful,” and as being “fantastic at what they do.”
The interesting topics, fun activities, and comfortable class atmosphere contributed to student’s overwhelming satisfaction with this course. Despite its niche in the Fine Arts Department, students unanimously “recommend it to any student at Penn.” One student summed up the course as “AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME” repeatedly, and others praised it as the “highlight of my undergraduate career.”
